SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to compose a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: THOMAS T. TAYLOR

2. Your address: HAMMOND, SASKATCHEWAN

3. Date: May 25th, 1967

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): WHITLEY, YORKSHIRE, Eng

5. What was your father's name and occupation? HENRY TAYLOR - he was a farm bailiff or farm steward, on one farm for 40 years in Yorkshire.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): July 1st, 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

Being on my honeymoon, I started in Toronto & worked until the harvest season started. Went there we came to Canada. Went to work on a farm.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).

I was 27 years, being born in 1877

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

Being tired of the prospects of a working man in Scotland, the abuse of those about you to be seen doing more than a share of the normal work, being too much with the Red Band of the Red Cross, Colonist or working in literature, decided to go.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).

Through the literature of the Red Band or the correspondence of Red Band.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

I don't know what they thought as they didn't expect me there at the time but in 1946 they did.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

My wife & I being on honeymoon travelled alone with the exception of a couple of people we met on the boat.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Boat & Train to Arcola, Later 1946

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

Although there was no roads at that time only over the town of Regina, it was rough riding over the prairies. The only excitement was the meeting of two bands of Indians on active area, but we had seen them quite a few times around Carlyle & Arcola previously.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

My wife & I both worked on a farm 4 miles South of Arcola.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

S.W. of 36-28-5 W 3rd or about 21 miles S. 15 of Halloway.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

None

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Growing fruit & tropical plants under glass, previous to that farming. I knew after 40 years on the one farm as a small "place that farmer" I am retired since my son came home from the war. I now hold of the farm in the fall of 1945.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Regularly every few weeks, when our relatives were able to work. Our wife was dead, so my children were all gone at work.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Cyrus Foster. We were married at Wolseley, Canada, on the 16th day of June 1904.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

Yes, several. Brothers & their families.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Two of the brothers who came West settled on Farms in the Lance District north of Swift Current, but only one is left. The other two are still living near Edmonton.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

When I came to this Western Country, I was struck by the readily gained access to information of every kind to each other, especially in the case of sickness or other adversities to the free social life. The good times and dances in the homes, often of God but warm.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

In the early days, we got all the travel we needed as often as we could. We had an automobile and our nearest town to get food was Havelock, where we used to haul wood for fire from the Sandhills near Danburn, a round trip of 150 miles. Times a week often to save time & what little money we had for the summer. While instead of going to a coffee house, we used to go to a nearby settlement, watching up a team of oxen hauling out to sell trips at 20° below. It was good for your health!
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   I have never owned a car.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? (Reasons to 1918)
   where the most new. The main line came through here. Stanley, Winkler & Easton to 1918.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   When ever we had to go, we had the money.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   After the C.P.R. came in here in 1906 they started Saturday shopping day.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   We did quite a little mail order business with groceries & clothes purchased after the Railway came in as we had little money & had to get as much as we could for that little we had.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes, after the move I worked for during my first harvest. He told me that the crop on our particular half section we harvested that fall had paid for the land; it was on the breaking of it. The seed in seeding of it & the harvesting of it. So I made up my mind not try it.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

No, but lots in the 20s. Then again in the 1920s where we had so many dyes.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Yes I myself have held many offices although I have no dedication having gone off work in 1886 at the age of 17 years. I have been president of the Agricultural Society, Bank Sec. Coop., the Local Board, late chair of the Wheat Pool Committee for 23 years, also E. Sec. & Finance Sec. President of the dealer but could get none of succession.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give; (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

While I cannot say why this Town was named Hartland it has been named after the "Good Old Days" Gladstone's estate in the "Old Country". The streets here are named after his family.

P.S. I'm afraid I haven't answered these questions as you would have liked them answered but I've done what I could. Thank you very much.

Thomas T. Taylor
37. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?.... (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?
